sp.p: A hammer! (looking round) let's ſee, what have we here—Sir Richard, heir to Robert—a genealogy in full, egad—Here, Careleſs, you ſhall have no common bit of monogany, here's the family tree, and now you may knock down my anceſters with their own pedigree.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: What an unnatural rogue he is!— An expert facto paracide. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: Gad, Charles, this is lucky, for it will not only ſerve for a hammer, but a catalogue too if we ſhould want it.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: True—Come, here's my great uncle Sir Richard Ravelin, a marvelous good General in his day—he ſerved in all the Duke of Marlborough's wars, and got that cut over his eye at the battle of Malplaquet—He is not dreſſed out in feathers like our modern captains, but enveloped in wig and regimentals, as a General ſhould be.—What ſay you, Mr. Premium?

sp.speaker: Moſes.
sp.p: Mr. Premium would have you ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why you ſhall have him for ten pounds, and I'm ſure that's cheap enough for a ſtaff officer.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Heaven deliver me! his great uncle Sir Richard going for ten pounds— (Aſide)—Well, ſir, I take him at that price.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Careleſs, knock down my uncle Richard.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: Going, going—a going—gone.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: This is a maiden ſiſter of his, my great aunt Deborah, done by Kneller, thought to be one of his beſt pictures, and eſteemed a very formidable likeneſs. There ſhe ſits, as a ſhepherdeſs feeding her flock.—You ſhall have her for five pounds ten. I'm ſure the ſheep are worth the money.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Ah, poor aunt Deborah! a woman that ſet ſuch a value on herſelf, going for five pounds ten— (Aſide)—Well, ſir, ſhe's mine.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Knock down my aunt Deborah, Careleſs.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: Gone.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Here are two couſins of their's—Moſes, theſe pictures were done when beaux wore perewigs, and ladies their own hair.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Yes, truly—head-dreſſes ſeem to have been ſomewhat lower in thoſe days.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Here's a grandfather of my mother's, a judge well known on the weſtern circuit. What will you give for him?

sp.speaker: Moſes.
sp.p: Four guineas.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Four guineas? why you don't bid the price of his wig. Premium, you have more reſpect for the Wool Sack, do let me knock him down at fifteen.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: Gone.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p:
Here are two brothers, William and Walter Blunt, Eſquires, both members of Parliament,
and great ſpeakers; and what's very extraordinary, I believe this is the firſt time they were ever bought or ſold.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: That's very extraordinary indeed!— I'll take them at your own price, for the honour of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Well ſaid Premium.

sp.speaker: Careleſs
sp.p: I'll knock 'em down at forty pounds— Going—going—gone.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Here's a jolly, portly fellow, I don't know what relation he is to the family, but he was formerly Mayor of Norwich, let's knock him down at eight pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: No. I think ſix is enough for a Mayor.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Come, come, make it guineas, and I'll throw you the two Aldermen into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: They are mine.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Careleſs, knock down the Mayor and Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: Gone.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: But hang it, we ſhall be all day at this rate; come, come, give me three hundred pounds, and take all on this ſide the room in a lump.— And that will be the beſt way.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Well, well, any thing to accommodate you; they are mine.—But there is one portrait you have always paſſed over.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: What, that little ill-looking fellow over the ſettee.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, 'tis that I mean—but I don't think him ſo ill-looking a fellow by any means.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: That's the picture of my uncle Oliver— before he went abroad it was done, and is eſteemed a very great likeneſs.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: That your uncle Oliver! Then in my opinion you will never be friends, for he is one of the moſt ſtern looking rogues I ever beheld; he has an unforgiving eye, and a damn'd diſinheriting countenance. Don't you think ſo, little Premium?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I do not, Sir; I think it as honeſt a looking face as any in the room, dead or alive.—But I ſuppoſe your uncle Oliver goes with the reſt of the lumber.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: No hang it, the old gentleman has been very good to me, and I'll keep his picture as long as I have a room to put it in.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: The rogue's my nephew, after all—I forgive him every thing. (Aſide) but Sir, I have ſome how taken a fancy to that picture.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it, Maſter Broker, for you certainly won't have it—What the devil, have you not got enough of the family?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: I forgive him every thing. (Aſide) Look, Sir, I am a ſtrange ſort of a fellow, and when I take a whim in my head I don't value money: I'll give you as much for that as for all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Praythee don't be troubleſome—I tell you I won't part with it, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: How like his father the dog is—I did not perceive it before, but I think I never ſaw ſo ſtrong a reſemblance. (Aſide) Well, Sir, here's a draft for your ſum. (giving a bill.)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why this bill is for eight hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: You'll not let Sir Oliver go, then.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: 〈…〉 all.

sp.speaker: Sir 〈◊〉
sp.p:
〈…〉 me your hand
(preſſes it) you are a damn'd honeſt fellow, Charles— O Lord! I beg pardon, Sir, for being ſo free—come along Moſes.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: But hark'ye, Premium, you'll provide good lodgings for theſe gentlemen, (going.)

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: I'll ſend for 'em in a day or two.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: And pray let it be a genteel conveyance, for I aſſure you moſt of 'em have been uſed to ride in their own carriages.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: I will for all but Oliver.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: For all but the honeſt little Nabob.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: You are fixed on that.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Peremtorily.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Ah the dear extravagant dog! (Aſide) Good day, Sir. Come Moſes.—Now let me ſee who dares call him profligate.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: Why, Charles, this is the very prince of Brokers.

sp.speaker: Charles.
Careleſs.
sp.p: But hark'ye, Charles, don't let that fellow make you part with any of that money to diſcharge muſty old debts. Tradeſmen, you know, are the moſt impertinent people in the world.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: True, and paying them would only be encouraging them.

sp.speaker: Careleſs.
sp.p: Well, ſettle your buſineſs, and make what haſte you can.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p:
Eight hundred pounds! Two-thirds of this are mine by right—five hundred and thirty odd pounds!—Gad, I never knew till now that my anceſtor were ſuch valuable acquaintance—Kind ladies
and gentlemen, I am your very much obliged, and moſt grateful humble ſervant. (bowing to the pictures)
Ah, old Rowley, you are juſt come in time to take leave of your old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, I heard they were going.—But how can you expreſs ſuch ſpirits under all your misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: That's the cauſe, Maſter Rowley; my misfortunes are ſo many, that I can't afford to part with my ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: And can you really take leave of your anceſtors with ſo much unconcern?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Unconcern! what, I ſuppoſe you are ſurprized that I am not mere ſorrowful at loſing the company of ſo many worthy friends. It is very diſtreſſing to be ſure; but you ſee they never move a muſcle, then why the devil ſhould I?

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Ah, dear Charles!—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: But come, I have no time for trifling;— here take this bill and get it changed, and carry an hundred pounds to poor Stanley, or we ſhall have ſomebody call that has a better right to it.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Ah, Sir I wiſh you would remember the proverb—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: "be juſt before you are generous."— Why fool would if I could, but juſtice is an old, lame, hobbling beldame, and I can't get her to keep pace with generoſity for the ſoul of me.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Do, dear Sir, reflect.

sp.speaker: Charles.

div.stage: And enter Sir OLIVER and MOSES.

sp.speaker: Moſes.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I think, as Sir Peter ſaid, you have ſeen Mr. Charles in all his glory—'tis great pity he's ſo extravagant.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: True, but he would not ſell my picture.—

sp.speaker: Moſes.
sp.p: And loves wine and women ſo much.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: But he would not ſell my picture.—

sp.speaker: Moſes.
sp.p: And games ſo deep.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: But he would not ſell my picture.— Oh, here comes Rowley.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I find you have made a purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Yes, our young rake has parted with his anceſtors like tapeſtry.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: And he has commiſſioned me to return you an hundred pounds of the purchaſe money, but under your fictitious character of old Stanley. I ſaw a taylor and two noſiers dancing attendance, who, I know will go unpaid, and the two hundred pounds would juſt ſatisfy them.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll pay his debts and his benevolence too.—But now I'm no more a broker, and you ſhall introduce me to the elder brother as old Stanley.

sp.speaker: Trip.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'm ſorry I was not in the way to ſhew you out. Hark'ye Moſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: There's a fellow, now—Will you believe it, that puppy intercepted the Jew on our coming, and wanted to raiſe money before he got to his maſter.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p:
And they are now planning an annuity buſineſs.—Oh, Mr. Rowley, in my time ſervants were
content with the follies of their maſters, when they were wore a little threadbare; but now they have their vices, like their birth-day cloaths, with their gloſs on.

div.head: SCENE the Apartments of JOSEPH SURFACE.

sp.speaker: JOSEPH.
sp.p: NO letter from Lady Teazle.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I wonder ſhe did not write if ſhe could not come—I hope Sir Peter does not ſuſpect me—but Charles's diſſipation and extravagance are great points in my favour (knocking at the door)—ſee if it is her.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: 'Tis Lady Teazle, ſir; but ſhe always orders her chair to the milliner's in the next ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Then draw that ſcreen—my oppoſite neighbour is a maiden Lady of ſo curious a temper—you need not wait. (Exit ſervant)—My Lady Teazle, I'm afraid begins to ſuſpect my attachment to Maria; but ſhe muſt not be acquainted with that ſecret till I have her more in my power.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: What, ſentiment in ſoliloquy!—Have you been very impatient now? Nay, you look ſo grave,—I aſſure you I came as ſoon as I could.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Oh! madam, punctuallity is a ſpecies of conſtancy—a very unfaſhionable cuſtom among ladies.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Nay, now you wrong me; I'm ſure you'd pity me if you knew my ſituation— (both ſit)— Sir Peter grows ſo peeviſh, and ſo ill natured, there's no enduring him; and then, to ſuſpect me with Charles.—

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I'm glad my ſcandalous friends keep up that report.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: For my part, I wiſh Sir Peter to let Maria marry him—Wou'dn't you Mr. Surface?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: (Aſide) Indeed I would not.—Oh, to be ſure; and then my dear Lady Teazle would be convinced how groundleſs her ſuſpicions were, of my having any thoughts of the ſilly girl.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Then there's my friend Lady Sneerwell, has propagated malicious ſtories about me—and what's very provoking, all too without the leaſt foundation.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Ah! there's the miſchief; for when a ſcandalous ſtory is believed againſt me, there's no comfort like the conſciouſneſs of having deſerved it.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: And to be continually cenſured and ſuſpected, when I know the integrity of my own heart—it would almoſt prompt me to give him ſome grounds for it.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Certainly, for when a huſband grows ſuſpicious, and withdraws his confidence from his wife, it then becomes a part of her duty to endeavour to out wit him.—You owe it to the natural privilege of your ſex.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Oh, yes; for your huſband ſhould never be deceived in you, and you ought to be frail in compliment to his diſcernment.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: This is the neweſt doctrine.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Very wholeſome, believe me.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: So, the only way to prevent his ſuſpicions, is to give him cauſe for them.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: But then the conſciouſneſs of my innocence.—

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Ah, my dear lady Teazle, 'tis that conſciouſneſs of your innocence that ruins you.—What is it that makes you imprudent in your conduct, and careleſs of the cenſures of the world? The conſciouſneſs of your innocence—What is it makes you regardleſs of forms, and inattentive to your huſband's peace? Why, the conſciouſneſs of your innocence.—Now my dear Lady Teazel, if you could only be prevailed upon to make a trifling faux pas, you cant imagine how circumſpect you would grow.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Depend upon it.—Your caſe at preſent, my dear Lady Teazle, reſembles that of a perſon in a plethora—you are abſolutely dying of too much health.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Why, indeed if my underſtanding could be convinced.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Your underſtanding!—Oh, yes your underſtanding ſhould be convinced. Heaven forbid that I ſhould perſuade you to any thing that is wrong. No, no, I have too much honour for that.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Don't you think you may as well leave honour out of the queſtion? (both riſe)

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Ah, I ſee, Lady Teazle, the effects of country education ſtill remain.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: They do, indeed, and I begin to find myſelf imprudent; and if I ſhould be brought to act wrong, it would be ſooner from Sir Peter's ill treatment of me, than from your honourable logic, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Then by this hand which is unworthy— (knowing, a ſervant enters)—What do you want you ſcoundrell?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I beg pardon, ſir—I thought you would not chuſe Sir Peter ſhould come up.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Sir Peter!

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Sir Peter! Oh, I'm undone!—What ſhall I do? Hide me ſomewhere, good Mr. Logic.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Here, here, behind this ſcreen (ſhe runs behind the ſcreen) and now reach me a book. (Sits down, and reads.)

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Aye, there he is, ever improving himſelf —Mr. Surface, Mr. Surface.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: (Affecting to gape.) Oh, Sir Peter!—I rejoice to ſee you—I was got over a ſleepy book here— I am vaſtly glad to ſee you—I thank you for this call— I believe you have not been here ſince I finiſhed my library.—Books, books, you know, are the only thing I am a coxcomb in.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Very pretty, indeed,—why even your ſcreen is a ſource of knowledge—hung round with maps I ſee.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Yes, I find great uſe in that ſcreen.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ſo you muſt when you want to find any thing in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Yes, or to hide any thing in a hurry

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: But my dear friend, I want to have ſome private talk with you.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: You need not wait.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Pray ſit down— (both ſit)—My dear friend I want to impart to you ſome of my diſtreſſes.— In ſhort, Lady Teazle's behaviour of late has given me very great uneaſineſs. She not only diſſipates and deſtroys my fortune, but I have ſtrong reaſons to believe ſhe has formed an attachment elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I am unhappy to hear it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Yes, and between you and me, I believe I have diſcovered the perſon.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: You alarm me exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I know you would ſympathize with me.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir Peter, ſuch a diſcovery would affect me—juſt as much as it does you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What a happineſs to have a friend we can truſt, even with our family ſecrets.—Can't you gueſs who it is?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I hav'n't the moſt diſtant idea.—It can't be Sir Benjamin Backbite.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No, no,—What do you think of Charles?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: My brother! impoſſible!—I can't think he would be guilty of ſuch baſeneſs and ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Ah, the goodneſs of your own mind makes you ſlow to believe ſuch villainy.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Very true, Sir Peter.—The man who is conſcious of his own integrity of heart, is very ſlow to credit another's baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: And yet, that the ſon of my old friend ſhould practiſe againſt the honour of my family.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Aye, there's the caſe, Sir Peter,—when ingratitude barbs the dart of injury, the wound feels double ſmart.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What noble ſentiments!—He never uſed a ſentiment, ungrateful boy! that I acted as guardian to, and who was brought up under my eye; and I never in my life refuſed him—my advice.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I don't know, Sir Peter,—he may be ſuch a man—if it be ſo, he is no longer a brother of mine; I renounce him, I diſclaim him.—For the man who can break through the laws of hoſpitality, and ſeduce the wife or daughter of his friend, deſerves to be branded as a peſt to ſociety.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: And yet, Joſeph, if I was to make it public, I ſhould only be ſneered and laughed at.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Why, that's very true—No, no, you muſt not make it public, people would talk.—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Talk.—They'd ſay it was all my own fault; an old doating batchelor to marry a young giddy girl. They'd paragraph me in the news-papers, and make ballads on me.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: And yet, Sir Peter, I can't think that my Lady Teazle's honour.—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Ah, my good friend, what's her honour, oppoſed againſt the flattery of a handſome young fellow.—But Joſeph, ſhe has been upbraiding me of late, that I have not made her a ſettlement; and I think, in our laſt quarrel, ſhe told me ſhe ſhould not be very ſorry if I was dead. Now I have drafts of two deeds for your peruſal, and ſhe ſhall find, if I was to die, that I have not been inattentive to her welfare while living. By the one, ſhe will enjoy eight hundred pounds a year during my life; and by the other, the bulk of my fortune after my death.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: This conduct is truly generous.—I wiſh it mayn't corrupt my pupil.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: But, I would not have her as yet acquainted with the leaſt mark of my affection.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Nor I—if you could help it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: And now I have unburthened myſelf to you, let us talk over your affair with Maria.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable upon the ſubject now, (alarmed)—Some other time; I am too much affected by your affairs to think of my own. For the man who can think of his own happineſs, while his friend is in diſtreſs, deſerves to be hunted as a monſter to ſociety.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I am ſure of your affection for her.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Let me intreat you Sir Peter.—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: And though you are ſo averſe to Lady Teazle's knowing it. I aſſure you ſhe is not your enemy, and I am ſenſibly chagrined you have made no furthur progreſs.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Sir Peter, I muſt not hear you—The man who— (enter ſervant) What do you want ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Your brother, ſir, is at the door talking to a Gentleman; he ſays he knows you are at home, that Sir Peter is with you, and he muſt ſee you.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I'm not at home.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you ſhall be at home.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: (after ſome heſitation) Very well, let him come up.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Now, Joſeph, I'll hide myſelf, and do you tax him about the affair with my Lady Teazle, and ſo draw the ſecret from him.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: O fie! Sir Peter,—what join in a plot to trepan my brother!

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Oh aye, to ſerve your friend;—beſides, if he is innocent, as you ſay he is, it will give him an opportunity to clear himſelf, and make me very happy. Hark, I hear him coming—Where ſhall I go? Behind this ſcreen—What the devil! here has been one liſtner already, for I'll ſwear I ſaw a petticoat.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p:
(Affecting to laugh) It's very ridiculous, ha! ha! ha!—a ridiculous affair, indeed—ha! ha! ha! Hark ye Sir Peter (pulling him aſide) though I hold a man of intrigue to be a moſt deſpicable character, yet you know it does not follow, that one is to be an abſolute Joſeph either. Hark ye, 'tis a little French
milliner, who calls upon me ſometimes, and hearing you were coming, and having ſome character to looſe, ſhe ſliped behind the ſcreen.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: A French milliner! (ſmiling) cunning rogue! Joſeph—fly rogue—But zounds, ſhe has over heard every thing that has paſſed about my wife.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Oh, never fear—Take my word it will never go farther for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Won't it?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: No, depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Well, well, if it will go no farther— but—where ſhall I hide myſelf.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Here, here, ſlip into this cloſet, and you may over hear every word.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Can I ſteal away.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Huſh! huſh! don't ſtir.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Joſeph, tax him home.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: In, my dear Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Can't you lock the cloſet door?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Not a word—You'll be diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Joſeph, don't ſpare him.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake lie cloſe—A pretty ſituation I am in, to part man and wife in this manner.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: You're ſure the little French Milliner won't blab.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why, how now, brother, your fellow denied you, they ſaid you were not at home.—What, have you had a Jew wench with you?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Neither, brother, neither.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: But where's Sir Peter? I thought he was with you.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: He was, brother; but hearing you was coming, he left the houſe.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What, was the old fellow afraid I wanted to borrow money of him?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Borrow! no brother; but I'm ſorry to hear you have given that worthy man cauſe for great uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Yes, I am told I do that to a great many worthy men—But how do you mean brother?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Why he thinks you have endavoured to alienate the affections of Lady Teazle.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Who, I alienate the affections of Lady Teazle!—Upon my word he accuſes me very unjuſtly. What has the old gentleman found out that he has got a young wife, or what is worſe, has the Lady found out that ſhe has got an old huſband.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: For ſhame, brother.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I did once ſuſpect her Ladyſhip had a partiality for me, but upon my ſoul, I never gave her the leaſt encouragement, for you know my attachment was to Maria.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: This will make Sir Peter extremely happy. —But if ſhe had a partiality for you, ſure you would not have been baſe enough—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why, look ye, Joſeph, I hope I ſhall never deliberately do a diſhonourable action; but if a pretty woman ſhould purpoſely throw herſelf in my way, and as that pretty woman ſhould happen to be married to a man old enough to be her father.—

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why then, I believe I ſhould—have occaſion to borrow a little of your morality brother.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Oh fie, brother—The man who can jeſt—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, that's very true, as you were going to obſerve.—But Joſeph, do you know that I am ſurprized at your ſuſpecting me with Lady Teazle, I thought you was always the favourite there.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Me!—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why yes, I have ſeen you exchange ſuch ſignificant glances.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Yes, I have; and don't you remember when I came in here, and caught her and you at—

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I muſt ſtop him (Aſide.) (Stops his mouth) Sir Peter has over-heard every word that you have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir Peter! where is he?—What, in the cloſet—'Foregad I'll have him out.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: No, no. (Stopping him.)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I will—Sir Peter Teazle come into court. (Enter Sir Peter.) What, my old guardian turn inquiſitor, and take evidence incog.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Give me your hand.—I own, my dear boy, I have ſuſpected you wrongfully, but you muſt not be angry at Joſeph, it was all my plot, and I ſhall think of you as long I live for what I overheard.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Then 'tis well you did not hear more. Is it not Joſeph?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What you would have retorted on Joſeph, would you?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: And yet you might as well have ſuſpected him as me. Might not he Joſeph?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: (Whiſpering Joſeph)—Lady Sneerwell, ſir, is juſt coming up, and ſays ſhe muſt ſee you.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I muſt beg your pardon, I have company waiting for me, give me leave to conduct you down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: No, no, ſpeak to 'em in another room; I have not ſeen Sir Peter a great while, and I want to talk with him.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Well, I'll ſend away the perſon and return immediately. Sir Peter, not a word of the little French Milliner.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Ah, Charles, what a pity it is you don't aſſociate more with your brother, we might then have ſome hopes of your reformation, he's a young man of ſuch ſentiments.—Ah, there's nothing in the world ſo noble as a man of ſentiment.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh, he's too moral by half, and ſo apprehenſive of his good name, that I dare ſay, he would as ſoon let a prieſt into his houſe as a wench.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No, no, you accuſe him wrongfully— Though Joſeph is not a rake, he is no ſaint.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Oh! a perfect anchorite—a young hermit.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh, don't abuſe him, or he may chance to hear of it again.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why, you won't tell him will you?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No, no, but—I have a great mind to tell him (Aſide)— ſeems to heſitate)—Hark'ye, Charles, have you a mind for a laugh at Joſeph?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I ſhould like it of all things—let's have it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Gad I'll tell him—I'll be even with Joſeph for diſcovering me in the cloſet.— (Aſide.)— Hark'ye Charles, he had a girl with him when I called.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Who, Joſeph! impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Yes, a little French Milliner (takes him to the front) and the beſt of the joke is, ſhe is now in the room.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: The devil ſhe is—Where?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh—behind the ſcreen.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I'll have her out.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: By the Lord I will.—So now for't. Both run up to the ſcreen—ſcreen falls, at the ſame time

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Lady Teazle, by all that's wonderful!

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Lady Teazle, by all that's horrible!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir Peter, this is the ſmarteſt French milliner I ever ſaw. But pray what's the meaning of all this? You ſeem to have been playing at hide and ſeek here, and for my part, I don't know who's in or who's out of the ſecret.—Madam, will you pleaſe to explain? —Not a word!—Brother, is it your pleaſure to illuſtrate? —Morality dum too!—Well, though I can make nothing of it, I ſuppoſe you can perfectly underſtand one another, good folks, and ſo I'll leave you. Brother I am ſorry you have given that worthy man ſo much cauſe for uneaſineſs—Sir Peter, there's nothing in the world ſo noble as a man of ſentiment.— Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Sir Peter, notwithſtanding appearances are againſt me—if—if you'll give me leave—I'll explain every thing to your ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p:
Lady Teazle knowing any—Lady Teazle— I ſay—knowing my pretenſions—to your ward—Maria —and—Lady Teazle—I ſay—knowing the jealouſy of my—of your temper—ſhe called in here— in order that ſhe—that I—might explain—what theſe pretenſions were—And—hearing you were coming— and—as I ſaid before—knowing the jealouſy of your temper—ſhe—my Lady Teazle—I ſay—went behind
the ſcreen—and—This is a full and clear account of the whole affair.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: A very clear account truly! and I dare ſay the lady will vouch for the truth of every word of it.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: (Advancing) For not one ſyllable, Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What the devil! don't you think it worth your while to agree in the lie.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: There's not one word of truth in what that Gentleman has been ſaying.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Zounds, madam, you won't ruin me.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Stand out of the way, Mr. Hypocrite, I'll ſpeak for myſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Aye, aye,—let her alone—ſhe'll make a better ſtory of it than you did.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: I came here with no intention of liſtening to his addreſſes to Maria, and even ignorant of his pretenſions; but ſeduced by his inſidious arts, at leaſt to liſten to his addreſſes, if not to ſacrifice his honour, as well as my own, to his unwarrantable deſires.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Now I believe the truth is coming indeed.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: What! is the woman mad?

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p:
No, ſir, ſhe has recovered her ſenſes. Sir Peter, I cannot expect you will credit me; but the tenderneſs you expreſſed for me, when I am certain you did not know I was within hearing, has penetrated ſo deep into my ſoul, that could I have eſcaped the mortification of this diſcovery, my future life ſhould have convinced you of my ſincere repentance. As for that ſmooth tongued hypocrite, who
would have ſeduced the wife of his too credulous friend, while he pretended an honourable paſſion for his ward, I now view him in ſo deſpicable a light, that I ſhall never again reſpect myſelf for having liſtened to his addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Sir Peter—Notwithſtanding all this— Heaven is my witneſs—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: That you are a villain—and ſo I'll leave you to your meditations—

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Peter, you muſt not leave me— The man who ſhuts his ears againſt conviction—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Oh, damn your ſentiments—damn your ſentiments.

sp.speaker: JOSEPH.
sp.p: MR. Stanley!—why ſhould you think I would ſee Mr. Stanley; you know well enough he comes intreating for ſomething.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: They let him in before I knew of it; and old Rowley is with him.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p:
'Pſhaw, you blockhead; I am ſo diſtracted with my own misfortunes, I am not in a humour to ſpeak to any one—but ſhew the fellow up. [Exit ſervant.] Sure fortune never played a man of my policy ſuch a trick before—my character ruined with Sir Peter—my hopes of Maria loſt—I'm in a pretty humour to liſten to poor relations truly.—I ſhan't be be able to beſtow even a benevolent ſentiment on old
Stanley. Oh, here he comes; I'll retire, and endeavour to put a little charity in my face however.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: What, does he avoid us? That was him, was it not?

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; but his nerves are too weak to bear the ſight of a poor relation, I ſhould have come firſt to break the matter to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: A plague of his nerves—yet this is he whom Sir Peter extols as a man of a moſt benevolent way of thinking.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Yes, he has as much ſpeculative benevolence as any man in the kingdom, though he is not ſo ſenſual as to indulge himſelf in the exerciſe of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Yet he has a ſtring of ſentiments, I ſuppoſe, at his finger's ends.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: And his favourite one is, that charity begins at home.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: And his, I preſume, is of that domeſtic ſort, which never ſtirs abroad at all.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I'll leave you to introduce yourſelf, as old Stanley; I muſt be here again to announce you in your real character.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: True, and you'll afterwards meet me at Sir Peter's.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Without loſing a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Here he comes—I don't like the complaiſance of his features.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt obedient; I beg pardon for keeping you a moment—Mr. Stanley, I preſume.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: At your ſervice, ſir.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Pray be ſeated Mr. Stanley, I intreat you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Dear ſir, there's no occaſion. Too ceremonious by half.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Though I have not the pleaſure of your acquaintance, I am very glad to ſee you look ſo well. —I think, Mr. Stanley you was nearly related to my mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: I was, ſir, ſo nearly, that my preſent poverty I fear may do diſcredit to her wealthy children, elſe I would not preſume to trouble you now.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, don't mention that—For the man who is in diſtreſs has ever a right to claim kindred with the wealthy; I am ſure I wiſh I was of that number, or that it was in my power to afford you even a ſmall relief.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: If your uncle Sir Oliver was here, I ſhould have a friend.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I wiſh he was, you ſhould not want an advocate with him, believe me.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: I ſhould not need one, my diſtreſſes would recommend me. But I imagined his bounty had enabled you to be the agent of his charities.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, you are miſtaken; avarice, avarice,) Mr. Stanley is the vice of age; to be ſure it has been ſpread abroad that he has been very bountiful to me, but without the leaſt foundation, though I never choſe to contradict the report.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: And has he never remitted you bullion, rupees, or pagodas?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Oh, dear ſir, no ſuch thing. I have indeed received ſome trifling preſents from him, ſuch as ſhawls, avadavats, and Indian crackers; nothing more, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p:
There's gratitude for twelve thouſand
pounds! (Aſide.) Shawls, avadavats, and Indian crackers!

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Not I for one. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Oh, the ſums I have lent him!—Well, 'twas an amiable weakneſs—I muſt own I can't defend it, though it appears more blameable at preſent, as it prevents me from ſerving you, Mr. Stanley, as my heart directs.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Diſſembler— (Aſide)—then you cannot aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I am very unhappy to ſay it's not in my power at preſent; but you may depend upon hearing from me when I can be of any ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Sweet ſir you are too good.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Not at all, ſir; to pity without the power to relieve, is ſtill more painful than to aſk and be denied. Indeed, Mr. Stanley, you have me deeply affected. Sir, your moſt devoted; I wiſh you health and ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Your ever grateful and perpetual (bowing low) humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I am extremely ſorry, ſir, for your misfortunes— Here, open the door.—Mr. Stanley your moſt devoted.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Your moſt obliged ſervant. Charles you are my heir.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p:
This is another of the evils that attend a man's having ſo good a character—It ſubjects him to the importunity of the neceſſitous—the pure and ſterling are of charity, is a very expenſive article in the
catalogue of a man's virtues; whereas the ſentimental French plate I uſe, anſwers the purpoſe full as well, and pays no tax. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Mr. Surface, your moſt obedient; I wait on you from your uncle who is juſt arrived. (Gives him a note.)

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: How! Sir Oliver arrived!—Here, Mr. —call back Mr. Stanley.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: It's too late, ſir, I met him going out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Was ever any thing ſo unfortunate! (Aſide) —I hope my uncle has enjoyed good health and ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Oh, very good, ſir; he bid me inform you he'll wait on you within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Preſent him my kind love and duty, and aſſure him I'm quite impatient to ſee him, (Bowing.)

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: I ſhall, ſir.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Pray do, ſir (bows)—This was the moſt curſed piece of ill-luck.

div.head: SCENE Sir PETER TEAZLE'S Houſe.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Indeed, madam, my Lady will ſee no one at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Did you tell her it was her friend Mrs. Candour?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I did, madam, and ſhe begs to be excuſed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p:
Go again, for I am ſure ſhe muſt be greatly diſtreſſed. (Exit Maid) How provoking to be kept waiting I am not miſtreſs of half the circumſtances;
—I ſhall have the whole affair in the newspapers, with the parties names at full length, before I have dropped the ſtory at a dozen houſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Benjamin, I am glad you are come; have you heard of Lady Teazle's affair? Well, I never was ſo ſurprized—and I am ſo diſtreſſed for the parties.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Nay, I can't ſay I pity Sir Peter, he was always ſo partial to Mr. Surface.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Mr. Surface! Why it was Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Oh, no, madam, Mr. Surface was the gallant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: No, Charles was the lover; and Mr. Surface, to do him juſtice, was the cauſe of the diſcovery; he brought Sir Peter, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Oh, my dear madam, no ſuch thing; for I had it from one—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Yes, and I had it from one, that had it from one that knew—

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: And I had it from one—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: No ſuch thing—But here comes my Lady Sneerwell, and perhaps ſhe may have heard the particulars.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Oh, dear Mrs. Candour, here is a ſad affair about our friend Lady Teazle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure poor thing, I am much concerned for her.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: I proteſt ſo am I—though I muſt confeſs ſhe was always too lively for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: But ſhe had a great deal of good nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: And had a very ready wit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: But do you know all the particulars. (To Lady Sneerwell.)

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Yet who could have ſuſpected Mr. Surface?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Charles you mean.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: No, Mr. Surface.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Oh, 'twas Charles.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Charles!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Yes, Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: I'll not pretend to diſpute with you Mrs. Candour; but be it as it may, I hope Sir Peter's wounds won't prove mortal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Sir Peter's wounds! what! did they fight! I never heard a word of that.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: No!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: No!—

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Nor I, a ſyllable; Do, dear Sir Benjamin, tell us.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Oh, My dear madam, then you don't know half the affair—Why—why—I'll tell you— Sir Peter, you muſt know, had a long time ſuſpected Lady Teazle's viſits to Mr. Surface.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: To Charles you mean.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: No, Mr. Surface—and upon going to his houſe, and finding Lady Teazle there, ſir, ſays Sir Peter, you are a very ungrateful fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Aye, that was Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Mr. Surface.—And old as I am, ſays he, I demand immediate ſatisfaction: upon this, they both drew their ſwords, and to it they ſell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour,
sp.p: That muſt be Charles, for it is very unlikely that Mr. Surface ſhould fight him in his own houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: 'Sdeath madam, not at all. Lady Teazle, upon ſeeing Sir Peter in ſuch danger ran out of the room in ſtrong hyſteries, and was followed by Charles, calling out for hartſhorn and water. They fought, and Sir Peter received a wound in his right ſide by the thruſt of a ſmall ſword.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Piſtols! Piſtols! Nephew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Crabtree, I am glad you are come; now we ſhall have the whole affair.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: No, no, it was a ſmall ſword, uncle.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Zounds, nephew, I ſay it was a piſtol.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: A thruſt in ſecond through the ſmall guts.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: A bullet lodged in the thorax.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: But give me leave, dear uncle, it was a ſmall ſword.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: I tell you it was a piſtol—Won't you ſuffer any body to know any thing but yourſelf.— It was a piſtol, and Charles—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Aye! I knew it was Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Mr. Surface, uncle.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Why zounds, I ſay it was Charles, muſt no body ſpeak but yourſelf. I'll tell you how the whole affair was.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell. Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Ah do, do pray tell us.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: I ſee my uncle knows nothing at all about the matter.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p:
Mr. Surface you muſt know, Ladies, came late from Salt-hill, where he had been the evening before with a particular friend of his, who has a ſon at Eton; his piſtols were left on the bureau,
and unfortunately loaded, and on Sir Peter's taxing Charles—

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Mr. Surface you mean.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Do, pray, nephew, hold your tongue, and let me ſpeak ſometimes.—I ſay, Ladies, upon his taking Charles to account, and taxing him with the baſeſt ingratitude.—

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Aye, Ladies, I told you Sir Peter taxed him with ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: They agreed each to take a piſtol— They fired at the ſame inſtant—Charles's ball took place, and lodged in the thorax. Sir Peter's miſſed, and what is very extraordinary, the ball grazed againſt a little bronze Shakeſpeare that ſtood over the chimney, flew off through the window, at right angles, and wounded the poſt man, who was juſt come to the door with a double letter from Northamptonſhire.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: I heard nothing of all this! I muſt own, Ladies, my uncle's account is more circumſtantial, though mine is the true one.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: I am more intereſted in this affair than they imagine, and muſt have better information.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Lady Sneerwell's alarm is very eaſily accounted for.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Why, yes; they do ſay—but that's neither here nor there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: But pray, where is Sir Peter now? I hope his wound won't prove mortal.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: He was carried home immediately, and has given poſitive orders to be denied to every body.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: And I believe Lady Teazle is attending him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: I do believe ſo too.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Certainly—I met one of the faculty as I came in.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Gad ſo! and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Yes, yes, that's the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: That certainly muſt be the phyſician —Now we ſhall get information.

div.p: Dear Doctor how is your patient?

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: I hope his wounds are not mortal.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Is he in a fair way of recovery.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Pray, Doctor, was he not wounded by a thruſt of a ſword through the ſmall guts?

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Was it not by a bullet that lodged in the thorax.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Nay, pray anſwer me?

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Dear, dear Doctor ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Hey, hey, good people, are you all mad?—Why what the devil is the matter?—a ſword through the ſmall guts, and a bullet lodged in the thorax! What would you all be at?

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Then perhaps, ſir, you are not a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: If I am, ſir, I am to thank you for my degree.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: Only a particular friend, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Nothing more, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Then I ſuppoſe, as you are a friend, you can be better able to give us ſome account of his wounds.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Wounds!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: What! havn't you heard he was wounded—The ſaddeſt accident.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: A thruſt with a ſword through the ſmall guts.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: A bullet in the thorax.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Good people, ſpeak one at a time, I beſeech you—You both agree, that Sir Peter is dangerouſly wounded.

sp.speaker: Crabtree. Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we both agree in that.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Then I will be bold to ſay, Sir Peter is one of the moſt imprudent men in the world, for here he comes walking as if nothing had happened.
My good friend, you are certainly mad to walk about in this condition; you ſhould go to bed, you that have had a ſword through your ſmall guts, and a bullet lodged in your thorax.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: A ſword through my ſmall guts and a bullet lodged in my thorax!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Yes theſe worthy people would have killed you without law or phyſic, and wanted to dub me a Doctor, in order to make me an accomplice.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What is all this!

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: Sir Peter, we are all very glad to find the ſtory of the duel is not true.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: And exceedingly ſorry for your other misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: So, ſo all over the town already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Though, as Sir Peter was ſo good a huſband, I pity him ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Plague of your pity.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: As you continued ſo long a batchelor, you was certainly to blame to marry at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire you'll conſider this is my own houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: However, you muſt not be offended at the jeſts you'll meet on this occaſion.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: It is no uncommon caſe, that's one thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I inſiſt upon being maſter here; in plain terms I deſire you'll leave my houſe immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Candour.
sp.p: Well, well, ſir, we are going, and you may depend upon it, we ſhall make the beſt of the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Sir Benjamin.
sp.p: And tell how badly you have been treated.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Leave my houſe directly.

sp.speaker: Crabtree.
sp.p: And how patiently you bare it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Leave my houſe, I ſay,—Fiends, furies, there is no bearing it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Well, Sir Peter, I have ſeen my Nephews.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: And Sir Oliver is convinced, your judgment is right after all.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Aye, Joſeph is the man.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Such ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: And acts up to the ſentiments he profeſſes.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis edification to hear him talk.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: He is a pattern for the young men of the age.—But how comes it Sir Peter, that you don't join in his praiſes?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Sir Oliver, we live in a damned wicked world, and the fewer we praiſe the better.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Right, right, my old friend—But was you always ſo moderate in your judgement?

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Do you ſay ſo, Sir Peter? You never was miſtaken in your life.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Oh, plague of your jokes—I ſuppoſe you are acquainted with the whole affair.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: I am indeed, ſir.—I met Lady Teazle returning from Mr. Surface's ſo humbled, that ſhe deigned to beg even me to become here advocate.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What! does Sir Oliver know it too?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Aye, aye, every circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What! about the cloſet and the ſcreen.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Yes, and the little French milliner too. I never laughed more in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: And a very pleaſant jeſt it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: This is your man of ſentiment, Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Oh, damn his ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: You muſt have made a pretty appearance when Charles dragged you out of the cloſet.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Yes, yes, that was very diverting.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: And, egad Sir Peter, I ſhould like to have ſeen your face when the ſcreen was thrown down.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: My face when the ſcreen was thrown down! oh yes!—There's no bearing this. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: come, come, my old friend, don't be vexed, for I can't help laughing for the ſoul of me. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Oh, laugh on—I am not vexed—no, no, it is the pleaſanteſt thing in the world. To be the ſtanding jeſt of all one's acquaintance, 'tis the happieſt ſituation imaginable.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: See, ſir, yonder's my Lady Teazle coming this way, and in tears, let me beg of you to be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll leave Rowley to mediate between you, and take my leave; but you muſt make haſte after me to Mr. Surface's, where I go, if not to reclaim a libertine, at leaſt to expoſe hypocriſy.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I'll be with you at the diſcovery; I ſhould like to ſee it, though it is a vile unlucky place for diſcoveries. Rowley (looking out) ſhe is not coming this way.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: No, ſir, but ſhe has left the room door open, and writs your coming.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Well, certainly mortification is very becoming in a wife.—Don't you think I had better let her pine a little longer.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, that's being too ſevere.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I don't think ſo; the letter I found from Charles was evidently intended for her.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Peter, you are much miſtaken,

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: If I was convinced of that—ſee, Maſter Rowley, ſhe looks this way—What a remarkable elegant turn of the head ſhe has—I have a good mind to go to her.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Do, dear ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: But when it is known that we are reconciled▪ I ſhall be laughed at more than ever.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Let them laugh on, and retort their malice upon themſelves, by ſhewing them you can be happy in ſpite of their ſlander.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Faith, and ſo I will, Maſter Rowley, and my Lady Teazle and I may ſtill be the happieſt couple in the country.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Oh fie, Sir Peter he that lays aſide ſuſpicion—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: My dear Rowley, if you have any regard for me, never let me hear you utter any thing like a ſentiment again; I have had enough of that to laſt me the remainder of my life.

div.head: SCENE JOSEPH'S Library.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Impoſſible! Will not Sir Peter be immediately reconciled to Charles, and no longer oppoſe his union with Maria.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Can paſſion mend it.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: No, nor cunning neither. I was a fool to league with ſuch a blunderer.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Sure, my Lady Sneerwell, I am the greateſt ſufferer in this affair, and yet, you ſee, I bear it with calmneſs.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Becauſe the diſappointment does not reach your heart; your intereſt only was concerned. Had you felt for Maria, what I do for that unfortunate libertine your brother, you would not be diſſuaded from taking every revenge in your power.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Why will you rail at me for the diſappointment.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Are you not the cauſe? Had you not a ſufficient field for your roguery in impoſing upon Sir Peter, and ſupplanting your brother, but you muſt endeavour to ſeduce his wife. I hate ſuch an avarice of crimes; 'tis an unfair monopoly, and never proſpers.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Well, I own I am to blame—I have deviated from the direct rule of wrong, Yet, I cannot think circumſtances are ſo bad as your Ladyſhip apprehends.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p:
You tell me you have made another trial
of Snake, that he ſtill proves ſteady to our intereſt, and that he is ready, if occaſion requires, to ſwear to a contract having paſſed between Charles and your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Why, the letters which have been ſo carefully circulated, will corroborate his evidence, and prove the truth of the aſſertion. But I expect my uncle every moment, and muſt beg your Ladyſhip to retire into the next room.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: But if he ſhould find you out.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I have no fear of that—Sir Peter won't tell for his own ſake, and I ſhall ſoon find out Sir Oliver's weak ſide.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Nay, I have no doubt of your abilities▪ only be conſtant to one villainy at a time.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Well, I will, I will.— (Exit Lady Sneerwell) —It is confounded hard though, to be baited by one's confederate in wickedneſs— (knocking —Who have we got here? My uncle Oliver, I ſuppoſe—Oh, old Stanley again! How came he here? He muſt not ſtay—
I told you already, Mr. Stanley, that it was not in my power to relieve you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver
sp.p: But I hear, ſir, that Sir Oliver is arrived, and perhaps he might.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Well, ſir; you cannot ſtay now, ſir; but any other time, ſir, you ſhall certainly be relieved.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: • h, Sir Oliver and I muſt be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I 〈◊〉 upon your going. Indeed, Mr. 〈◊〉 , you can't ſtay.

sp.speaker: Sir Olive • .
sp.p: Poſitively I muſt ſee Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Then poſitively you ſhan't ſtay.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Hey day! what's the matter? Why, who the devil have we got here? What, my little Premium. Oh, brother, you muſt not hurt my little broker. But hark'ye Joſeph, what have you been borrowing money too.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Borrowing money! no brother—We expect my uncle Oliver here every minute, and Mr. Stanley inſiſts upon ſeeing him.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Stanley! Why his name is Premium.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: No, no! I tell you his name is Stanley.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: But I tell you again his name is Premium.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: It don't ſignify what his name is.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: No more it don't, as you ſay brother, for I ſuppoſe he goes by half a hundred names, beſides A. B. at the Coffee-houſes. But old Noll muſt not come and catch my little broker here neither.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Mr. Stanley, I beg—

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: And I beg Mr. Premium—

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: You muſt go indeed, Mr. Stanley.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Aye, you muſt go, Mr. Premium.

div.stage: Enter Sir PETER, Lady TEAZLE, MARIA, and ROWLEY.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What, my old friend Sir Oliver! what's the matter?—In the name of wonder were there ever two ſuch ungracious nephews, to aſſault their uncle at his firſt viſit.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: On my word, ſir, it was well we came to your reſcue.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Charles!

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Joſeph!

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Now our ruin is complete.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: You find, Sir Oliver, your neceſſitous character of old Stanley could not protect you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: No! nor Premium neither. The neceſſities of the former could not extract a ſhilling from that benevolent Gentleman there, and with the other I ſtood a worſe chance than my anceſtors, and had like to have been knocked down without being bid for. Sir Peter, my friend, and Rowley, look upon that elder Nephew of mine▪ you both know what I have done for him, and how gladly I would have looked upon half my fortune as held only in truſt for him. Judge then, of my ſurpriſe and diſappointment, at finding him deſtitute of truth, charity, and gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Sir Oliver, I ſhould be as much ſurpriſed as you, if I did not already know him to be artful, ſelfiſh and hypocritical.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: And if he pleads not guilty to all this, let him call upon me to finiſh his character.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Then I believe we need not add more, for if he knows himſelf, it will be a ſufficient puniſhment for him that he is known by the world.

sp.speaker: Charles▪
sp.p: If they talk this way to honeſty, what will they ſay to me by and by.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: As for that profligate there— (pointing to Charles.)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ay, now comes my turn; the damn'd family pictures will ruin me.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: Sir Oliver, will you honour me with a hearing?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p:
Now if Joſeph would make one of his
long ſpeeches, I ſhould have time to recollect myſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you would undertake to juſtify yourſelf entirely.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: I truſt I could, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw (turns away from him) and I ſuppoſe you could juſtify yourſelf too.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Not that I know of, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: What, my little Premium was let too much into the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why yes, ſir; but they were family ſecrets, and ſhould go no further.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Come, come, ſir Oliver, I am ſure you cannot look upon Charles's follies with anger.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: No, nor with gravity neither.—Do you know, ſir Peter, the young rogue has been ſelling me his anceſtors: I have bought judges and ſtaff officers by the foot, and maiden aunts as cheap as old china. (During this ſpeech, Charles laughs behind his hat.)

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Why, that I have made free with the family canvas is true, my anceſtors may riſe in judgment againſt me, there's no denying it, but believe me when I tell you (and upon my ſoul I would not ſay it, if it was not ſo) if I don't appear mortified at the expoſure of my follies, it is, becauſe I feel at this moment the warmeſt ſatisfaction, at ſeeing you my liberal benefactor. (embraces him.)

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Charles, I forgive you; give me your hand again, the little ill-looking fellow over the ſettee has made your peace for you.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Then, ſir, my gratitude to the original is ſtill increaſed.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Sir Oliver, here is another, with whom I dare ſay Charles is no leſs anxious to be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: I have heard of that attachment before, and with the Lady's leave—if I conſtrue right, that bluſh—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Well, child, ſpeak for yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I have little more to ſay, than that I wiſh him happy, and for any influence I might once have had over his affections, I moſt willingly reſign them to one who has a better claim to them.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Hey! what's the matter now? While he was a rake and a profligate, you would hear of nobody elſe; and now that he is likely to reform, you won't have him. What's the meaning of all this.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: His own heart, and Lady Sneerwell can beſt inform you.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Lady Sneerwell!

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
Sir Peter.
sp.p: Another French milliner!—I believe he has one in every room in the houſe.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: Ungrateful Charles! Well you may ſeem confounded and ſurprized, at the indelicate ſituation to which your perfidy has reduced me.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Pray uncle is this another of your plots? for, as I live, this is the firſt I ever heard of it.

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p: There is but one witneſs, I believe, neceſſary to the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p:
And that witneſs is Mr. Snake—you were perfectly in the right in bringing him with you.
〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Deſire Mr. Snake to walk in.—It is rather unlucky, madam, that he ſhould be brought to confront, and not ſupport your Ladyſhip

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: I am ſurprized! what, ſpeak villain! have you too conſpired againſt me?

sp.speaker: Snake.
sp.p: I beg your Ladyſhip ten thouſand pardons; I muſt own you paid me very liberally for the lying queſtions, but I have unfortunately been offered double for ſpeaking the truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Plot and counter-plot—I give your Ladyſhip much joy of your negociation.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: May the torments of deſpair and diſappointment light upon you all. (going.)

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Hold, Lady Sneerwell; before you go, give me leave to return you thanks, • or the trouble you and this gentleman took, in writing letters in my name to Charles, and anſwering them yourſelf;— and, at the ſame time, I muſt beg you will preſent my compliments to the ſcandalous college, of which you are preſident, and inform them, that Lady Teazle, licentiate, returns the diploma they granted her, as ſhe leaves off practice, and kills characters no longer.

sp.speaker: L. Sneerwell.
sp.p: You too, madam! Provoking inſolent! may your huſband live theſe fifty years.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Oh, Lord—what a malicious creature it is!

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Not for her laſt wiſh I hope.

sp.speaker: L. Teazle.
sp.p: Oh, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Well, ſir—what have you to ſay for yourſelf? (to Joſeph.)

sp.speaker: Joſeph.
sp.p:
Sir, I am ſo confounded that Lady Sneerwell ſhould impoſe upon us all, by ſuborning Mr.
Snake, that I know not what to ſay—but—leſt her malice ſhould prompt her to injure my brother— I had better follow her.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Moral to the laſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Marry her, Joſeph, marry her if you can—Oil and Vinegar—you'll do very well together.

sp.speaker: Rowley.
sp.p: Mr. Snake, I believe, we have no further occaſion for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Well,—averſe to ſentiments, as I am yet I cannot help obſerving, that when a knave ſucceeds in his deſigns upon credulity, he can boaſt of nothing more than having been a while miſtaken for an honeſt man; but it would be better, for the continuance and completion of his happineſs, were he to become, for life, and in reality, what he has only ſeemed to be.
